args: I'm pretty sure I came that way while\nI avoided the imperial army, so—
I'll be right behind you! Now go!
I heard screaming and came to see\nif I could help.
Well, we're alive because of you.\nIf there's anything we can do,\nplease let us know.
Well, I'm actually in a bit of trouble\nmyself, so I'd be relieved if you could\nhelp me.
So you got yourself lost, huh?\nWell, we'd be happy to take you\nas far as our village.
If you follow the path from there,\nyou can get where you're headed.
That would be great, thank you.
This is our village! It's called Araba.
(Araba? That's under the Empire's control.\nI'd better get out of here as soon as I can.)
Ho, there you are! We were getting\nworried about the two of you!
We were attacked by fiends and saved\nby this good soul here.
Gracious! This village owes you a\nmighty debt, sir.
I only did what anyone would.\nEr, and not to be rude, but I really\nneed to be on my way.
W-wait, sir! Merely showing you to\nthis village is not enough to repay\nthe debt we owe you!
At least let us prepare you a meal\nbefore you're on your way!
Well, I suppose one meal wouldn't hurt...
Hmm... I've seen that man before...
And just then he came running in and\ntook down the enemy with a single blow!
I don't know if I'd go quite THAT far...
Chief, might I have a moment?\nOh, and you'll want to hear this as well.
What do you need me for?
The man you brought back to the village\nis the traitor prince!
What?! But that's the most wanted man\nin the Empire! I hear he's been fomenting\nchaos and sedition everywhere he goes!
He doesn't seem so bad to me.
That's because you haven't seen him on\nthe battlefield like I have.
I watched him transform into a ferocious\ndragon and slaughter our comrades.
He's not a man—he's a MONSTER!
If we don't report this to the Empire,\nthey'll assume we support his treason.
But that man saved my daughter's life,\nas well as my own!
And yet, we don't have a choice.\nWe must report this man.
Chief! You're on board with this?!
It would mean rebuke or worse for our\nvillage if the Empire discovered that\nwe knowingly harbored him.
(I thought there was something strange\ngoing on over here, but I never expected\nit would be THIS...)
They will betray you someday, just as\nthey did him. They WILL reject you.
(I have to sneak away from this place\nbefore things get out of hand.)
How can you even SAY that?!
That man saved you AND me!\nHe's a good person!
You know nothing, girl! That is\nno man at all, but a monster!
I don't wanna hurt someone\nwho helped us!
Listen to me, all of you.
Yes, but I'm leaving. Now. Once I'm gone,\ngo immediately to the Imperial Army and\ntell them how you discovered me here.
This is the only way. If you don't,\nyour village will suffer for it.
Go to them. Tell them I ran off after\nyou stumbled upon me sneaking around.
So we are to reward your kindness\nby setting the Empire on your trail?!
That's exactly what you're going to do.\nBesides, I didn't help you in hopes of\na reward—I did it because it was right.
Damn, it's the Imperial Army!\nI didn't leave fast enough!
To think a village of the Dyrenell Empire\nwould harbor a rebel like this!
N-no! You've got it all wrong!
Silence! I hereby name the villagers\nof Araba to be traitors to the Empire!
Enough! They had nothing to do with this!\nIt's me you want, so come and take me!
Trying to protect your fellow rebels, eh?\nPut this village to the torch, men!\nDo not permit a single soul to live!
I tried to be reasonable about this,\nbut you've left me no choice!
That ought to be the end of it.\nAre you people all right?
Good. But if the Empire comes back,\nyou all need to flee to the Halidom.
Why are you still helping us?
We just tried to sell you out!
Some of you did so, yes.\nBut others tried to aid me.
I wanted to protect the people here,\nso I fought. That's all there is to it.
Anyway, I'll be off. I'm sorry I got you\nwrapped up in this, and I pray you\nnever have to deal with it again.
Just having people I want to protect\nis reason enough for me to fight.
Too much strength is isolating,\nbut I know now a means of\nenduring that isolation.
...I wonder if Alberius thought the\nsame way.
